[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_delete_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Authorization Bypass] Can an attacker exploit a race condition between authority transfer (set_authority) and deletion, where validate() checks old authority but actuate() executes after authority change, allowing unauthorized deletion? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_delete_action.move] [Function: has_authority()] [Authorization Logic] Does has_authority() at line 19 properly validate ctx.sender() against aggregator.authority, or can an attacker spoof the sender address through transaction manipulation to bypass the authority check? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_delete_action.move] [Function: run()] [Multi-sig Bypass] If the aggregator authority is supposed to require multi-sig approval, can a single authority holder call run() directly to delete the aggregator without other signers' consent, violating governance invariants? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_delete_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Time-of-Check-Time-of-Use] Between validate(&aggregator, ctx) at line 34 and actuate(aggregator) at line 35, can external state changes (queue updates, oracle updates) invalidate the validation, creating a TOCTOU vulnerability? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_delete_action.move] [Function: run()] [Authority Revocation] If aggregator authority is revoked or transferred between transaction submission and execution, does validate() at line 34 properly fail, or can a revoked authority still delete the aggregator? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_delete_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Delegated Authority] If the Aggregator supports delegated authority patterns, does has_authority() at line 19 only check direct authority match, missing delegated authorities who should also be able to delete? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_delete_action.move] [Function: run()] [Emergency Pause Bypass] Is there any emergency pause mechanism in the Aggregator that should prevent deletion during critical operations, but run() bypasses by not checking pause status before deletion? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_delete_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Authority Type Confusion] Can an attacker exploit type confusion if aggregator.authority is not properly type-checked, passing an object that satisfies has_authority() but isn't the legitimate authority address? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_delete_action.move] [Function: run()] [Batch Deletion Attack] Can an attacker with authority over multiple aggregators call run() in a batch transaction to delete all critical oracle feeds simultaneously, causing mass DoS for dependent Volo Vault operations? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_delete_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Authority Inheritance] If Aggregator authority can be inherited through object ownership chains, does has_authority() at line 19 properly validate the entire ownership chain, or can intermediate owners be bypassed? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_delete_action.move] [Function: run()] [Front-running Authority Transfer] Can a malicious old authority front-run their authority transfer transaction to delete the aggregator before the new legitimate authority takes control, griefing the new owner?
